title: Introduction to the Linked Data Mining Challenge

author: Petar Ristoski, School of Business Informatics and Mathematics, University of Mannheim

segmentation: So hello everybody, welcome to the link Data Mining Challenge 2015.
I'm Peter and we organized this challenging collaboration between the University of Mannheim and University of Economic Impact.
Also, this year challenge consists of 1 classification task.
That's more precisely the task is to actually predict the review class of movies.
This is a binary classification problem where the classes are good an bad.
So the data set was collected from metacritic.com, which offers a list of movies with some ratings.
And the objective of the challenge was to actually use some linked open data sets and other publicly available datasets to build predictive models to for the given task.
Alsometacritic.com offers average ratings of all time reviews for 10,000 movies.
We said that it also offers some basic information about the movies like short summary about the movie, director cost and so on.
So to generate.
Deal set for the challenge.
We first link each movie from Metacritic to the corresponding CDP entities using.
Move the movie's title and movies director.
Also, Metacritic also categorize these movies into three classes.
That is good movies of all movies that have rating above 60 are considered to be good movies.
Then all movies between 60 and 40 are considered to be neutral and below 40 are bad movies.
So to simplify the task, we simply remove the neutral class and that not only simplifies the task in terms of the number of classes, but also it creates a bigger gap between the bad and good movies.

So to generate the final deal set we selected 1000 movies from the top of this list and 1000 movies from the bottom of the list, which actually increases the gap even more between the between the movies.
02 to separate the data set in training and test set, we used.
We selected random.

We use this random stratified rule with 8020 split the final training data set contained 1600 movies, so where for each movie we provide the idea of the movie The movie title, release date, the DP DUI and the final label.
So this deal set was given to the participants to build.
Predictive models, and so afterwards they could apply this predictive models on the test data set with which contained 400 movies.
So from this data set we removed the label and the participants were actually supposed to predict this label.
To evaluate the approaches, we use the three criteria.
First is the performance of the model, of course, which was measured in terms with accurate.

2nd is the originality of the approach and techniques that were used so that includes the data preprocessing techniques, the the feature engineering will techniques like which data sets were used, how the features were generated, how were selected and filter out and also the machine learning approaches like which approaches were used and how the parameters for selected and how are tuned.
And Thirdly, we also evaluate the validity of the hypothesis and findings described in the paper, like observation.
What makes a movie to be good or to be bad?
Although the participants were allowed to use the any linked open data as a background knowledge, like for example, the pedia, the link to movie database DB drops, and so on.
They were also allowed to use any other public data set, but only if they make this deal.
Sets of accessible via RDF or Sparkle endpoint, and also they have to add the corresponding DP links in those externally assets.
And also they were not allowed to use the new Metacritic data set itself.
All the submission procedure was implemented to the online system where the users could simply simply just submit their results and they will get the results of the performance results.
And also there was a real time leaderboard which was a listing all participants and their results.
So it was interesting to fold the challenge online all the time.
So also we provided to baseline models.
The first one is Canon Classifier, where we use the direct types and.
And categories retrieve from DB pedia.
With this basically model we achieved around 60% accuracy and this process was actually built in rapidminer and was available for download.
So it was just like example 2 for the participants to see how can you build data mining model that actually use features from linked open data.
And also we provided the simple 0R classifier which simply.
Just predicts the majority class and this was just like the lowest baseline that can achieve.
So in the end we received four online submissions, all of them were actually better than the baselines.
And in the end we received only three, three submissions.
Solutions that actually provided the approach in the online system, and they also described it in a paper so they achieved rather high accuracy and they were really close to each other.
So for example, the first participant score to around 94.75% accuracy and the last one 95475%.
So in the end of the online submission.
Was over, we collected all submissions to actually make some further analysis of the approaches.
For example, we wanted to measure the degree of agreement among the three approaches about prediction of the classes.

For that we calculated simply the flights Copa, which is rather high, which means that there is good agreement between the three different approaches, but there is still some cases where they don't actually agree on what makes a good or bad movie.

Oh, and in the end we also on top of these three approaches we built Meta Learner, which uses a majority vote to predict the final class and this actually scored 97%, which is better than the best performing approach, which means that there is still room for improvement if multiple approaches are used for the prediction.
Oh, that would be all from me.
So if you don't have any questions.
